Egregious

adj:

Outstandingly bad, shocking. Conspicuously outrageous. Extreme, beyond any reasonable degree.

Egregious simplifies how you can take action to reduce amount of excessive plastic packaging used.

  • Scan a product barcode
  • Tweet or email the manufacturer
  • Ask them to do better

What is Egregious

We are all part of a complex and dependant relationship between manufacturer, supplier, and consumer. Sometimes it can feel so complex we cope by shutting down and consume as usual. This has taken a devastating toll on the planet.

At Egregious we don’t pretend to have all the answers, but we do have a belief that small actions gather momentum and bring about larger scale change.

We aim to make it simple for you to give the manufacturers a nudge and let them know that excess plastic packaging bothers you.

Manufacturers carry both power and wealth in this consumer-supplier relationship. Enough to research and find alternative packaging solutions and distribution systems. And we hope with enough nudging they will start to make changes.

How does it work

If you notice an item that bothers you, simply SCAN it and we identify the manufacturer. If you are linked to Twitter, you can tweet, or we generate a template email that is sent from you direct to direct to the manufacturer. You can of course customise this email.

Obviously, we have no influence in how that manufacturer deals with the email, they may bin it, divert it, and so on, but that isn’t the point. We want to gather data that shows the manufacturers that their customers are bothered.

This first website aims to gauge if there is a desire to use such a service. If so we hope to develop it into a smart phone app, maybe a community resource. Eventually we hope there will be no need for us to be doing this, and the manufacturers use of excessive plastic packaging will come to an end.

Who are we

The people involved in this are all volunteers, offering their time, expertise, and money to make this happen now. If this project grows we may need to look into how growth and development is paid for, but our aim is not financially motivated.

Andrew: Works as psychotherapist and ecotherapist working with how the climate emergency affects our mental health.

Richard: Works as a backend engineer who tries to build interesting things in his spare time. But mostly doesn't.
